message.content:
zy7o | Two. Food type and time - species use the same food at different times or different foods at the same time
kcar | Three. Habitat and time - species uses the same habitat at different times or different habitats at the same time
00aw | Four. Habitat and habitat - species overlapping in horizontal habitat often differ in vertical habitat or vice versa
351p | Five. Food type and food type - species may eat similar-sized foods but different species or types, or vice versa
zzcb | Differential Niche Overlap and Complementarity two
mxnx | · Seasonal (temporal) variation in habitat and dietary overlap among granivorous birds in an Arizonian grassland (spatio-temporal dietary niche segregation):
11k8 | · Rainy Season (food plenty): Birds specialize on a seed type across overlapping habitat types
twwy | · Dry Season (food scarce): Birds specialize on separate habitats foraging on many seed types
fyp8 | Differential Niche Overlap and Complementarity three
z994 | Differential Niche Overlap between four hypothetical species (A, B, C, D)
vvqn | · Horizontal niche dimension considered alone: Species C is apparently in trouble facing diffuse competition from both B and D - coexistence doubtful.
p6xg | · Vertical niche dimension considered alone: Species C subject to heavy niche overlap with A, and moderate overlap from B - coexistence doubtful.
bppc | · Both Niche dimensions considered simultaneously
ilnw | Resulting Niche Space
f3rc | · A, B, C versus D disjunct
d7bx | · A versus B disjunct
gx97 | · A and C abutting
ppkp | · Only little overlap between species B and C
8br6 | Differential Niche Overlap and Complementarity four
de3k | Foraging Techniques of five sympatric Bird Species in Oak Forest
2kb3 | · The time spent on three foraging tactics for each species monitored: One. Hovering, Two. Gleaning, Three. Hawking
lqcx | · All five species adopt all strategies, but to a variable degree.
3h7w | · Gleaners: Parus inornatus (tit), Vermivora celata (warbler).
th5p | · Hover-Gleaners: Vireo gilvus, V. huttoni (shrike-warblers).
b7nk | · Glean-Hover-Hawker: Polioptila caerulea (gnatcatcher)
cbb5 | · Differences in foraging techniques may reduce direct interference and also resource exploitation as each method is best designed for a particular prey type in a particular micro-habitat
5qcf | Equilateral Triangle
8u2c | Differential Niche Overlap and Complementarity five
c1e3 | Differential Niche Overlap and Complementarity six
7pez | Spatial Foraging Niche Separation of two water boatmen or bugs (Heteroptera)
qs5t | · Perch positions monitored quantitatively over time:
en4s | · Species (a) prefers near bottom (fifty-five percent), and least at water surface (five percent)
csb5 | · Species (b) prefers middle of water (fifty-eight percent), and least at water surface (seven percent)
i096 | · In this way they separate foraging depth and reduces competition
tlzt | Community Wide Niche Partitioning one
6iyf | Nine squirrel species in African rainforest:
o1nk | · Three Habitat types:
mnaf | · Dense growth (one species), Flooded forest (one species)
0yxe | · Mature and Disturbed Forest (seven species)
erre | · Trophic specialization (one species)
835g | · Bark scraping on tree trunks
x3l9 | · Frugivores separate spatially (six species):
d2fj | · Ground (three species) and Arboreal (three species)
geyi | · In each of the two vertical guilds, the three species separate on fruit size and hardness both of which is related to jaw musculature which again is related to mere body size.
2181 | Community Wide Niche Partitioning two
9ubl | Nineteen species of Coral Reef Fish at Great Barrier Reef, Australia:
o8pj | · Segregation into four main trophic levels (in which size and body shape vary):
27b9 | · Generalists: Typical fish shape, vary in size following Hutchinson's Rule
09xa | · Hard corals: Six Small (typical shape/ extra deep body), two large (deep body)
yi97 | · Soft and Hard corals (four species) three Large, one Small (all typical shape)
4zj7 | · Other invertebrates: Large (typical shape/ deep body)
3wgh | Niche Overlap, Partitioning and Coexistence
uvo3 | Summarizing Flow Chart showing the various ways that ecologically similar species may segregate or differentiate the overlap of their foraging niches (Birds)
yjbv | Summary: Differential Niche Overlap and Complementarity
l6it | One. Differential Niche Overlap comprises three major dimensions:
h8x1 | · Spatial: Horizontal (habitat types) and vertical (altitude, vegetation strata)
6qtq | · Temporal: Time of day or night, seasonal variation (dry or wet, summer or winter)
wm3n | · Trophic: Generalist or Specialist dietary trait, foraging techniques or strategies
1anr | Two. Niche Differentiation, Complementarity and Coexistence often interrelated:
600w | · Niche dimensionality leads to Niche differentiation leads to Complementarity
60w7 | · High niche differentiation predisposes Complementarity leads to Coexistence
1a5g | · High overlap in some niche dimensions tolerated by otherwise low overlaps
0oof | Summary: Differential Niche Overlap and Complementarity
p930 | Three. Community wide niche partitioning limits similarity and increase coexistence:
xhc7 | · High overlap in vertical and horizontal space leads to low trophic overlap
6a60 | · High dietary overlap leads to low, abutting, disjunct and spatial niches
dfgj | · High dietary and spatial overlap leads to low overlap in temporal niche
6ptp | Four. Coexistence facilitated by limiting similarity and hence niche overlap:
qjlj | · Spatial separation: vertical-horizontal habitat ranges, territoriality
kva7 | · Resource partitioning: Diet and foraging techniques diverging
ssp0 | · Morphological divergence: Body size, feeding apparatus (teeth, claws, beaks)
108o | ABCS three forty-nine: Objectives of Lecture six - Niche Partitioning and Species Richness
d2za | One. An Introduction to modelling of species richness using niche partitioning:
r38m | · What pertinent factors within the niche concept theory predicts diversity?
qq0z | · How are these factors interrelated and what are the dynamics among them?
rgva | Two. An Overview of various models to explain species numbers in space and time:
mlcd | · Are they mathematical stochastic or deterministic models?
2qe7 | · Graphically explained models to support the notational equations?
lpzf | · How does the models explain the links between niche dimensionality and how many species than can be packed into a natural system or community?
24rz | Three. A Comparison of various models to explain species numbers on islands:
091m | · The species-area models explained - islands and mainland islands
sot6 | · The island biogeography model: immigration to emigration to speciation to extinction
d6sf | Four. An Account of the theories behind speciation and extinction processes:
7haq | · What drives speciation in relation to niche overlap and competition?
ubwu | · What drives extinction in relation to niche overlap and competition?
ucme | Ds equals p (one plus Cã), where Du
qnl5 | · Based on MacArthur's model, communities diversity is shaped in three potentially interacting ways:
wdx9 | One. Resource base: How big is n in the niche hypervolume. Areas with more available resource have larger Dr and C components (niche space) and can therefore contain more species.
n1xr | Two. Niche width or degree of specialization of component species (Du) Narrow niches can be packed tighter and thus contain more species.
ohpj | Three. Niche overlap between species. Greater species overlap (smaller exclusive niches) leads to greater diversity even if two communities are similar in both areas.
ry5f | Four. Niche curve shape also counts, in thick-tailed (leptokurtic) curves more species can be packed on the same resource gradient than thin-tailed (platykurtic) curves
31wg | Niche Partitioning and Species Richness two
celk | Forest Succession and Increased Bird Diversity (Species Richness):
